Angelika Film Center & Cafe - New York

adrFormatAddress: 18 W Houston St, New York, NY 10012-1503, USA

editorialSummary.text: Popular venue for new indie & foreign films, shown on 5 screens, with on-premises cafe.

originalText.text: Nice movie theater specialized in indie and foreign movies. We've been there on a Saturday's morning to watch The Boy and the Heron. It was a nice experience! Don't expect for comfortable seats and huge screen - if your looking for that, that's not the place for you. But atmosphere is cozy and comforting. Audience was quiet during the whole movie - which helps with the experience. But the noise from subway was quite distracting. Anyway, a good experience overall.

text.text: Nice movie theater specialized in indie and foreign movies. We've been there on a Saturday's morning to watch The Boy and the Heron. It was a nice experience! originalText.text: Saw the boy and the heron here. Great theatre overall, seat layout is very different from AMC/other bigger chains, but it‚Äôs much better in my opinion. Also has great food options

originalText.text: Came here to attend The Last of Us immersive experience and the staff was amazing. Everyone was so nice, security was nice too and wished everyone fun. The only complaint I have and why I‚Äôm taking one star off is due to accessibility and seating. In regards to the seats, if you are let‚Äôs say over 250 pounds the seats will not be comfortable for you to sit in. If you are taller than 6 feet you will have no leg room as I standing at 5‚Äô9 had my knees touching the back of the chair in front of me the entire viewing.  Accessibility wise, I believe it‚Äôs steps and steps only. The theater I was in was located on the lower level of the theater which was, from as far as I know, only accessible by stairs. When it comes to getting to other levels of the theater I‚Äôm not sure. To get inside of the theater it‚Äôs also stairs only. Overall I‚Äôm glad I had the opportunity to attend the early viewing of the last of us

originalText.text: God, what happened to this joint?? Back in the day, it was the coolest theatre in Manhattan.  The films were arty and compelling, and it was very possible that you might spy a celebrity who probably lived in SOHO. Now, on a busy Saturday afternoon, the ticket window was closed, and neither of the two ticket kiosks was operable. The manager seemed harried and miserable, and the popcorn was just blah (it used to be the best, no ersatz butter needed!) I was trying to impress my bf who had never been, but it fell flat. And, the Crate and Barrel that had been on the corner for decades had closed.  It was a grim day,for sure.üò≠

text.text: God, what happened to this joint?? Back in the day, it was the coolest theatre in Manhattan.  The films were arty and compelling, and it was very possible that you might spy a celebrity who probably lived in SOHO. Now, on a busy Saturday afternoon, the ticket window was closed, and neither of the two ticket kiosks was operable. The manager seemed harried and miserable, and the popcorn was just blah (it used to be the best, no ersatz butter needed!) I was trying to impress my bf who had never been, but it fell flat. And, the Crate and Barrel that had been on the corner for decades had closed.  It was a grim day,for sure.üò≠
